title: Arizona's Water Systems
subtitle: An interactive story of the Salt River Project and the Central Arizona Project.
footer:
This story is based on presentations and information from:
Jacob Richardson, Salt River Project
Brian Buzard, Central Arizona Project
Ryan Johnson, Central Arizona Water Conservation District
Tom Buschatzke, Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR)

Salt River Project (SRP) | Central Arizona Project (CAP)

chapters.title: Central Arizona Project: A Lifeline from the Colorado
chapters.description: The Central Arizona Project (CAP) is a 336-mile aqueduct that brings water from the Colorado River to Central and Southern Arizona. It begins here, at Lake Havasu.

chapters.title: Following the CAP Canal
chapters.description: From Lake Havasu, a series of massive pumping plants lift the water, allowing it to flow south. The camera will now follow the general path of the canal, which is visible on the satellite imagery, as it makes its way toward Phoenix.

chapters.title: The Salt River Project
chapters.description: The Salt River Project (SRP) manages the Salt and Verde Rivers watershed. It operates a series of dams and reservoirs that provide a surface water supply to the Phoenix metropolitan area.

chapters.title: The Verde River Dams
chapters.description: The Verde River system is managed by two dams. This view shows both: Horseshoe Dam to the north and Bartlett Dam to the south. A marker will now visit each one.

chapters.title: 1. Horseshoe Dam (Verde River)
chapters.description: Horseshoe Dam, the most upstream dam on the Verde River, was completed in 1946. It serves primarily as a storage reservoir to capture runoff.

chapters.title: 2. Bartlett Dam (Verde River)
chapters.description: Downstream is Bartlett Dam. Completed in 1939, it was the world's highest multiple-arch dam at the time of its construction.

chapters.title: The Salt River Dams
chapters.description: The main branch of the SRP system is the Salt River itself, controlled by a staircase of four major dams. This view shows the chain of reservoirs they create. A marker will now visit each dam from east to west.

chapters.title: 1. Theodore Roosevelt Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: The system's cornerstone, Roosevelt Dam (1911), is the most upstream and forms the largest reservoir, providing the primary water storage.

chapters.title: 2. Horse Mesa Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: Downstream from Roosevelt, Horse Mesa Dam (1927) forms Apache Lake and is a key power generator.

chapters.title: 3. Mormon Flat Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: Next, Mormon Flat Dam (1925) creates Canyon Lake and features powerful pumped-storage hydro capabilities.

chapters.title: 4. Stewart Mountain Dam (Salt River)
chapters.description: The final dam, Stewart Mountain Dam (1930), forms Saguaro Lake before releasing water into the valley's canal system.

chapters.title: The Governing Agencies
chapters.description: Managing this complex system involves multiple key agencies. The Arizona Department of Water Resources (ADWR) oversees water rights and long-term planning, while the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) ensures water quality standards are met.
